Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Equity-Focused Approach to Integrating Physical Activity and CS Education for K-8 Learners
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project brings instruction in computing and data science to an elementary school with a predominantly Hispanic population through Project SMART, a digital educational game that uses students’ in-school physical activity to motivate student learning. Students record their physical activity during the school day, whether in physical education class, at recess, or at other teacher-provided opportunities for physical activity. An elementary school class plays collaboratively; the physical activity of all the students in the class is converted to a distance traveled along an extended virtual journey. The learning modules are defined by teachers and directly connected to the core curriculum. Key to the approach is that the computational learning activities provided introduce data collection, analysis, and prediction questions using the students’ own physical activity data. As such, the project explores research questions that are advancing the field's understanding about how to engage students in computer science. It also is investigating whether students are more engaged in, motivated by, and successful at computational thinking learning objectives if these objectives relate to data that is relevant to them: their physical activity, their interests, their environment, and, importantly, their own collected data.

This project expands and strengthens the Project SMART researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP), engaging researchers and teachers in collaborative efforts to identify strategies for computer science and computational thinking instruction that engages an elementary student population and addresses instructional challenges. These challenges include pressures to adhere to state standards that make it difficult to integrate additional content, a lack of at-home internet infrastructure that limits out-of-school student engagement, and teachers' lack of experience with and confidence in computer science content knowledge. Conjectures that orient the research plan explicate a premise that contextualizing computer science within the students' own physical activity during the regular school day as an integrated core subject lesson will help to address these challenges. In addition to advancing the field's understanding of a contextualized approach to data science instruction, this project also creates shareable learning modules that present data science learning activities that use the students' own physical activity to enable data modeling and prediction; guide students in hardware-software co-design to create wearable physical activity monitors that can improve data collection; and enable students to write code that extends the functions available in the game. This project is funded by the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Delivering computer science and computational thinking curriculum in elementary schools, especially those with traditionally underserved populations, faces a myriad of challenges that include pressures for all instructional time to be aligned with state standards, a lack of contextualization of computing curriculum, and teachers’ lack of experience and confidence in teaching computing content. The moveSMART project has the broad goal of developing and delivering contextualized computer science and computational thinking content in a Title I elementary school with a predominantly Hispanic student population, in a way that aligns with the constraints faced by elementary educators.


As part of the moveSMART project, we worked with elementary school teachers to create nine learning activities that achieve three objectives: (1) increasing students’ physical activity during instructional time; (2) improving students’ understanding of computer science and computational thinking concepts; and (3) delivering content that aligns with state educational standards in all subjects. These learning activities rely on the makecode programming environment and the micro:bit hardware platform to engage students in computer science learning by having them create programs that directly measure and record their physical activity. Students “test” their computer programs by being physically active. To build teacher capacity for teaching computer science and computational thinking content, we have also designed and introduced a template lesson guide for all nine moveSMART lessons. We offered professional development for elementary school teachers in a variety of formats.


Our project found that students’ attitudes towards computer science and computational thinking improved after engagement with the moveSMART platform, in particular with respect to their coding confidence and perception of coders. Because the learning activities in moveSMART include physical activity components and concepts that align with state learning standards, we found that they can be easily integrated into teachers’ curricula and used to reinforce learning in subjects as diverse as English Language Arts, Physical Education, and Mathematics.


Finally, the moveSMART project also developed and delivered teacher professional development, which also included opportunities for teachers to provide input about the integration of computer science and computational thinking with diverse elementary school subjects. Teachers identified novel ways to connect the computing content with reading and writing, particularly with reading comprehension. Notably, because the teachers identified these approaches themselves in a guided format, they were naturally compatible with the teacher’s own approach to the classroom. These discussions also fortified the community-based approach of moveSMART, and the fact that integrating computing instruction within the regular school day rather than as an extracurricular activity is essential for equitable access.
